content.description:
A scientist adds a chemical to a culture of dividing cells in order to disrupt <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> replication. The replicated <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> produced by the cells is double-stranded, but sections of it lack covalent bonds between adjacent nucleotides (Figure 1).

Figure 1. Replicated <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> produced after a chemical is introduced
content.question: Which of the following claims is best supported by the data?

choices.label: The chemical prevents the formation of <math alttext="R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> primers.
The chemical inhibits <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> ligase.
The chemical blocks <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> polymerase.

content.answer: The chemical inhibits <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> ligase.
